title: Die Stadt ohne Juden
descriptions:
Set in a fictionalized version of Vienna called Utopia, Die Stadt ohne Juden (The City Without Jews) imagines the social and political fallout after the government, driven by populist rhetoric and anti-Semitic agitation, passes a law expelling all Jewish residents. At first, the ruling politicians and many citizens celebrate, convinced that the Jews are to blame for economic woes, cultural disputes, and the supposed moral decline of the city. Trains shuttle families out under the watch of officials, and the city proclaims a fresh start.

The consequences are swift and devastating. Utopia’s economy falters as crucial merchants, financiers, artisans, and professionals vanish. Cultural life withers: theaters lose their performers and patrons, newspapers struggle, and cafés—once hubs of vibrant debate—grow empty and dull. The supposed moral “purity” yields only sterility. Foreign capital evaporates, trade contracts, unemployment rises, and the currency plunges. Even the everyday rhythm of city life—fashion, music, humor—turns gray and lifeless. Those who cheered the expulsions begin to realize how deeply Jewish citizens had been woven into the fabric of the city.

Amid this decline, satiric and romantic subplots unfold. A young non-Jewish man, in love with a Jewish woman forced into exile, becomes convinced that the expulsion has doomed the city. Disguising himself and using wit rather than force, he infiltrates political circles, lampoons the hypocrisy of the anti-Semitic leaders, and helps spark a movement to overturn the law. Meanwhile, in the diaspora, the expelled Jews struggle to rebuild their lives, a quiet contrast that underscores the human cost of bigotry and the absurdity of scapegoating.

Public opinion turns as shortages worsen and cultural stagnation becomes undeniable. Merchants and workers alike pressure the government, and the veneer of stability cracks. Ultimately, the ruling coalition, facing economic collapse and social unrest, rescinds the expulsion. Trains return, and the city welcomes back the people it cast out, realizing belatedly that its prosperity and spirit depend on pluralism. The romantic pair is reunited, but the film’s final irony lingers: the ease with which prejudice gained power, and the fragility of tolerance when demagogues exploit fear.

Made in 1924 as a satirical warning, the film envisions how a modern European city, by embracing intolerance, destroys itself—only recovering when it recognizes that diversity is essential to civic life.
